replace verb [T]
(CHANGE FOR)
B1 to take the place of something, or to put something or someone in the place of something or someone else: The factory replaced most of its workers with robots. Tourism has replaced agriculture as the nation's main industry.
B1 If you replace something broken, damaged, or lost, you provide a new one: I promised to replace the plate that I'd dropped.
More examplesFewer examplesDo a global search for 'organise' and replace it with 'organize'.The Council plans to knock the library down and replace it with a hotel complex.Imperial units have in many cases been replaced by metric ones in Britain.Doctors have replaced the top of his hip bone with a metal sphere.He's bought me a smart new camera to replace my old one.
